Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story: I stand behind the register, the soft beep of the scanner breaking the quiet of a slow afternoon. My phone buzzes in my pocket—our family group chat is alive with messages about this weekend. Mom wants everyone’s input for a family hike, and my little sister is already begging me to come. I know how much it means to them, especially since I’ve missed the last few outings. As I ring up a customer’s groceries, I try to type a quick reply, but my manager’s voice echoes in my head: “Stay focused, no distractions at the register.” I glance at the line—just two people, but I can’t afford to make a mistake. My hands move automatically, but my mind is split. I want to be the sibling who shows up, who laughs and makes memories, but right now, I’m the cashier who needs to be precise, attentive, and professional. The pressure builds as another message pops up, asking for my answer. I feel torn, caught between the family that needs me and the job that demands my full attention.
